1.brief: a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
Lemuel or Lemoel, a symbolic name of Solomon
a burden; specifically, tribute, or (abstractly) porterage; figuratively, an utterance, chiefly adoom, especially singing; mental, desire
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
to chastise, literally (with blows) or figuratively (with words); hence, to instruct
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))

2.brief: properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses

properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
the belly, especially the womb; also the bosom or body of anything

properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
a promise (to God); also (concretely) a thing promised

3.brief: not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
probably a force, whether of men, means or other resources; an army, wealth, virtue, valor, strength
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
properly, to stroke or rub; by implication, to erase; also to smooth (as if with oil), i.e. grease or make fat; also to touch, i.e. reach to

4.brief: not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
Lemuel or Lemoel, a symbolic name of Solomon
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
probably to be heavy, i.e. (figuratively) honorable
desire (and so probably in Proverbs 31:4); hence (by way of alternative) or, also if
an intoxicant, i.e. intensely alcoholic liquor

5.brief: properly, removal; used only (in the construction) adverb as conjunction, lest
to mislay, i.e. to be oblivious of, from want of memory or attention
properly, to hack, i.e. engrave (Judges 5:14, to be a scribe simply); by implication, to enact (laws being cut in stone or metal tablets in primitive times) or (gen.) prescribe
to fold, i.e. duplicate (literally or figuratively); by implication, to transmute (transitive or intransitive)
judgement (the suit, justice, sentence or tribunal); by implication also strife
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)

6.brief: to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
an intoxicant, i.e. intensely alcoholic liquor
properly, to wander away, i.e. lose oneself; by implication to perish (causative, destroy)
bitter (literally or figuratively); also (as noun) bitterness, or (adverbially) bitterly
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)

7.brief: to mislay, i.e. to be oblivious of, from want of memory or attention
toil, i.e. wearing effort; hence, worry, wheth. of body or mind
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to mark (so as to be recognized), i.e. to remember; by implication, to mention;  to be male
properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more

8.brief: to open wide (literally or figuratively); specifically, to loosen, begin, plough, carve
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
near, with or among; often in general, to
judgement (the suit, justice, sentence or tribunal); by implication also strife
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)

9.brief: to open wide (literally or figuratively); specifically, to loosen, begin, plough, carve
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
the right (natural, moral or legal); also (abstractly) equity or (figuratively) prosperity
a straight course, i.e. sail direct

10.brief: probably a force, whether of men, means or other resources; an army, wealth, virtue, valor, strength
who? (occasionally, by a peculiar idiom, of things); also (indefinitely) whoever; often used in oblique construction with prefix or suffix
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present
remote, literally or figuratively, of place or time; specifically, precious; often used adverbially (with preposition)

11.brief: figuratively, to trust, be confident or sure
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
a master; hence, a husband, or (figuratively) owner (often used with another noun in modifications of this latter sense)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to lack; by implication, to fail, want, lessen

12.brief: to treat a person (well or ill), i.e. benefit or requite; by implication (of toil), to ripen, i.e. (specifically) to wean

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively

13.brief: properly, to tread or frequent; usually to follow (for pursuit or search); by implication, to seek or ask; specifically to worship
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
pleasure; hence (abstractly) desire; concretely, a valuable thing; hence (by extension) a matter (as something in mind)
the hollow hand or palm (so of the paw of an animal, of the sole, and even of the bowl of a dish or sling, the handle of a bolt, the leaves of a palm-tree); figuratively, power

14.brief: to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
to travel round (specifically as a pedlar); intensively, to palpitate
remoteness, i.e. (concretely) a distant place; often (adverbially) from afar
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)

15.brief: to rise (in various applications, literal, figurative, intensive and causative)
properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more
properly, a twist (away of the light), i.e. night; figuratively, adversity
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
something torn, i.e. a fragment, e.g. a fresh leaf, prey, food
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
an enactment; hence, an appointment (of time, space, quantity, labor or usage)

16.brief: to plan, usually in a bad sense
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
the hollow hand or palm (so of the paw of an animal, of the sole, and even of the bowl of a dish or sling, the handle of a bolt, the leaves of a palm-tree); figuratively, power
properly, to strike in, i.e. fix; specifically, to plant (literally or figuratively)

17.brief: to gird on (as a belt, armor, etc.)
strength in various applications (force, security, majesty, praise)
properly, the waist or small of the back; only in plural the loins
to be alert, physically (on foot) or mentally (in courage)
the arm (as stretched out), or (of animals) the foreleg; figuratively, force

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to expire or (causatively) to extinguish (fire, light, anger)
properly, a twist (away of the light), i.e. night; figuratively, adversity
a lamp (i.e. the burner) or light (literally or figuratively)

to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)
literally a director, i.e. the spindle or shank of adistaff, by which it is twirled

to sustain; by implication, to obtain, keep fast; figuratively, to help, follow close
a circuit (i.e. district); also a spindle (as whirled); hence, a crutch

a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)

to fear; morally, to revere; caus. to frighten
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)

properly, wrap around, i.e. (by implication) to put on agarment or clothe (oneself, or another), literally or figuratively
crimson, properly, the insect or its color, also stuff dyed with it

22.brief: to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
bleached stuff, i.e. white linen or (by analogy) marble
purple (the color or the dyed stuff)
a garment (literally or figuratively); by implication (euphemistically) a wife

23.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
an opening, i.e. door or gate
a master; hence, a husband, or (figuratively) owner (often used with another noun in modifications of this latter sense)
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)

24.brief: to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
to sell, literally (as merchandise, a daughter in marriage, into slavery), or figuratively (to surrender)
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
a Kenaanite or inhabitant of Kenaan; by implication, a pedlar (the Canaanites standing for their neighbors the Ishmaelites, who conducted mercantile caravans)

a garment (literally or figuratively); by implication (euphemistically) a wife
to laugh (in pleasure or detraction); by implication, to play
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)

a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch

above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
the tongue (of man or animals), used literally (as the instrument of licking, eating, or speech), and figuratively (speech, an ingot, a fork of flame, a cove of water)

a walking; by implication, a procession or march, a caravan

a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
